Award.AwardTitle: REU Site in Molecular Genetics & Cell Biology at The University of Chicago
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the University of Chicago, located in Chicago, IL, will support the training of 8 students for 10 weeks, during the summers of 2014-2016. The program offers research training to improve understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the organization, development and mechanics of all living organisms. The Department of Molecular Genetics and Cell Biology has about 20 faculty members participating as mentors. The projects available in their laboratories are wide-ranging but all are focused on cutting edge research, using a variety of model organisms including viruses, bacteria, yeast, protozoa, fruit flies, plants, and nematode worms, and involving both biological manipulation and observation, and mathematical modeling. The 8 students each summer will engage in full-time lab research as well as participate in seminars and focused workshops on responsible conduct in research and scientific ethics, on how to prepare for advanced training in biological sciences, and on professional communication skills. REU students have access to the individual mentor's facilities as well as many core facilities such as advanced light microscopy, electron microscopy and tomography, next-generation DNA sequencing, and flow cytometry.

Students will be recruited to the program, particularly from disadvantaged groups, including through established informal collaborative agreements with a variety of undergraduate colleges. The program is focused on students attending institutions with limited research opportunities. Students are selected on the basis of their academic record and perceived potential for outstanding research, with preference given to those between their junior and senior years. Faculty mentors remain in contact with students after the program to determine their continued interest in their academic field of study, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of the BIO REU common assessment tool.

Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://mgcb.bsd.uchicago.edu/reu/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Aaron Turkewitz at apturkew@uchicago.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Lucia Rothman-Denes at lbrd@uchicago.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
We ran a program to offer Research Experiences for Undergraduates, in the fields of Molecular and Cell Biology.  Our program was specifically aimed at students who lack the opportunity, at the undergraduate institutions where they are enrolled, to pursue cutting edge biological research, and was further targeted to members of minority groups underrepresented in biology, as well as students from families that are economically disadvantaged or have no history of pursuing higher education.  Our active recruitment efforts resulted in a highly diverse and talented group . The program is a key part of outreach by our Department to broaden the participation of under-represented groups in research. The program supported 8 participants each summer with 1-2 potential additional participant(s) partially supported by summer supplements to NSF-grantee trainors. We received a total of 516 complete applications for the program during this period.

         Our REU students conducted original biology research, taking a wide variety of molecular approaches. Importantly, the program strongly fostered the development of peer relationships within the cohort of diverse scientifically focused individuals. These relationships developed because the students were all housed on a single hallway of a dormitory on campus, worked in a set of nearby laboratories, and met regularly as a group in a series of structured activities. The research itself, which formed the core of the program, was augmented with formal presentations from faculty members on their research, and workshops including advice on applying successfully to graduate school, on research ethics, and on non-academic careers for PhDs.

       The following are comments we received from students who participated in the program:

“I felt like the UChicago MGCB NSF REU program had a really positive impact on my career choices. Although I did not end up pursuing a PhD (instead a PharmD), the program taught me the necessary scientific practices I need to continue pursuing research throughout my career. The presentations by myself and fellow REU students throughout the course of the summer allowed me to both improve my presentation skills and be exposed to a broader range of projects. Again, this program is excellent, and really helps shape future scientists.”

 “I think it was an amazing opportunity because I learned so much. The hands-on techniques that I had only read about before really helped me. I think the best take-home from this internship was my ability to understand techniques at a deeper level and apply that to my classes senior year. I am extremely glad and thankful for the opportunity to attend the program.”

“The research experience at the UChicago REU was integral to my ability to perform well as soon as I entered my current lab. As Earlham does not have many available experiences for undergraduate research, the ability to spend a summer as part of the UChicago REU was critical to my scientific maturation. The program fostered what I believe will be a life-long passion for research. I am very grateful to have been included in the program, and hope it will continue to provide research opportunities for undergraduates like myself for many more years!”

 “I would vouch for/highly recommend this program to anyone interested!  I had a great experience, and I enjoyed the freedom and challenges of my project.  I felt that my participation in the REU gave me a really good understanding of both the process of research at a major research institution as well as the demands and rewards of pursuing a graduate education.  I could not have gained this experience at the small liberal arts university where I completed my undergraduate education. I honestly feel that my time at UChicago was very important in helping me become a successful graduate school applicant and a better scientist! “

 “This program was the most significant experience (scientifically and academically) I had ever had. The University of Chicago's vibrant scientific community, advanced research facilities, and welcoming faculty made my stay here unforgettable, which is the reason I chose UChicago out of other competitive schools to pursue my graduate studies. Most importantly, my participation in the NSF-REU allowed me to be in the position to choose from the best graduate programs in the world.”

 “The REU program not only taught me an extensive molecular based skill set that has primed me to pursue my future career goals, it gave me a taste of the professional research environment and provided me with the competitive edge I needed to succeed. I am extremely thankful for this program. After ten short weeks I became a more confident leader, detail oriented scientist and problem solver.”

“I think the REU program was an amazing opportunity and was really helpful in giving students a taste of what it would be like to live the life of a graduate student, and prepare them for the future should they choose to pursue PhD programs.”
